abstract: <jats:p>A Gram-negative bacterium, designated LA31B<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>, was isolated from water collected from a hypersaline lagoon on Laysan Atoll in the north-western Hawaiian Islands. Single cells of LA31B<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>were slightly curved but became helical as their length increased. Preliminary characterization based on 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis showed that LA31B<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>shared 96·0 % identity with an<jats:italic>Arcobacter</jats:italic>sp. isolated from a cyanobacterial mat in hypersaline Lake Sinai, and 94 % identity with<jats:italic>Arcobacter nitrofigilis</jats:italic>, the type species of the genus<jats:italic>Arcobacter</jats:italic>. A polyphasic taxonomic study was conducted and confirmed the phylogenetic affiliation of strain LA31B<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>to the genus<jats:italic>Arcobacter</jats:italic>. However, LA31B<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>was found to be distinct from all recognized<jats:italic>Arcobacter</jats:italic>species, by a comprehensive biochemical test analysis, whole-cell fatty acid profiling, DNA G+C content (35 mol% in LA31B<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>) and degree of DNA–DNA reassociation. Most notably, LA31B<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>was found to be an obligate halophile, a hitherto undescribed feature among recognized<jats:italic>Arcobacter</jats:italic>species. These data indicate that LA31B<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>should be considered to represent a novel species in the genus<jats:italic>Arcobacter</jats:italic>, for which the name<jats:italic>Arcobacter halophilus</jats:italic>sp. nov. is proposed. This is the first obligately halophilic member of the genus. The type strain is LA31B<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>(=ATCC BAA-1022<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>=CIP 108450<jats:sup>T</jats:sup>).</jats:p>
title: Arcobacter halophilus sp. nov., the first obligate halophile in the genus Arcobacter
